description: From Middle English bosart, from Anglo-Norman buisart, from Old French buison, buson (French buse), possibly from Latin buteō.

entries.meaning: Any of several Old World birds of prey of the genus Buteo with broad wings and a broad tail.
(Canada, US) Any scavenging bird, such as the American black vulture (Coragyps atratus) or the turkey vulture (Cathartes aura).
(colloquial, derogatory, slang, often preceded by "old", the "old buzzard") In North America, a curmudgeonly or cantankerous man; an old person; a mean, greedy person.

examples: An old man’s shadow is better than a young buzzard’s sword.
